The names say it all:
 
 Liberal (liber = free) is one who values liberty the most.
 Conservative (conservare = to save, to preserve, to maintain) is one who values stability/security the most.
 
 As one of the Founding Fathers (forgot which one) said: "He who sacrifices liberty for security deserves to lose both." I agree, therefore I am a liberal.
 
 BTW, current issues should have nothing to do with this. No honest and informed conservative can support Bush vs. Gore or the war in Iraq. And no honest and informed liberal can support the "political correctness" movement.

 - voluntary self-censorship (of Soviet proportions) during both wars with Iraq
 
 - misrepresentation of political alignment of the Supreme Court, constantly calling Souter and Breyer "liberals" and O'Connor and Kennedy "moderates"; also repeating the nonsense about liberals "legislating from the bench" and conservatives interpreting the Constitution literally
 
 - false "left-right" matches where the audience is presented with a moderate and a near-fascist (e.g. Paul Begala - Oliver North) and led to believe that the truth is halfway between those
 
 - general attitude that the rest of the world hardly exists
 
 Add the fact that a major media company (Fox) actively participated in the bushist coup, and the picture is complete.

And of course for a good while I have been vehemently against the Democrats on sodomy issues. I still tend to more agree with the Democrats on environmental and economic issues, so I'm rather split now what to think.
 
 I tend to agree with Christopher Hitchens that it is not that he became a conservative by supporting Bush in deciding the essentially fascist Iraqi regime should be forcibly removed, but that the democrats opted to become Chamberlainesque conservatives--to opt to do nothing to save others from tyranny. Insofar as it affects my opinion about Bush, I am not at all concerned whether he honestly thought there were WMD's in Iraq. If Bush knowingly stretched the truth about there being WMDs in Iraq, the likely reason was that he knew that even though he'd suffer politically in the long run before the next election, in the short term this would be a more politcally viable justification. In other words, he took a political risk mainly (I don't buy the cynical "he did it for Haliburton" slant) for the benefit of a repressed people. Hurrah!
 
 People talk about how dangerous Ashcroft is, and how he wants to censor everybody, etc. Well, I don't particularly like him either. But it's the anti-sodomy viewpoint that really is getting censored to hell nowadays. I wonder how many children get suspended or expelled nowadays for trying to help screwed-up kids by telling them that they ought to reform and be ashamed of themselves, under the guise of violating the sensitivities of gay people? (Not that teachers are allowed to do this, either.) If not many now, it won't be long the way things are going. I know that most of the major internet forums (but not this one, at least not yet) do not allow intelligent discussion of the evil of sodomy. After a while, I usually get censored, banned, or start having my anti-sodomy posts moved to the trash folders. This in forums full of all manners of nonsense and explicit talk.
 
 People ought to recall that Abraham Lincoln got nominated because of the strength of his position against judicial innovation--go read his Cooper Union speech, about how it's judicial innovation that leads to Dred Scott. Nowadays, the liberal members of the Supreme Court feel they can just eliminate by fiat laws like the Texas anti-sodomy law notwithstanding formerly all the states had such laws and obviously they were not considered unconstitutional by the framers of the Constitution or its Amendments. This is just plain dangerous and scary.
 
 It used to be that depravity was so universally derided, disgusting types more often had recourse to violence to addict others to their depravities. Nowadays, the sodomites have so beguiled the mass of the population it is more convenient for them to belittle just wars as being analogous to rescuing people from depravity than for them to glorify stupid wars as being analogous to rapacious violence. The Democratic foreign policy positions are screwed-up.
 
 Anyway, I don't know what to call myself anymore. An equal mix of far-left, far-right, and middle-of-the-road positions.

i'm a nationalist, because the labour party just land us with paper work and don't give us a say on anything; the conservatives have just turned into thatcherites under michael howard, and the lib-dems are just too liberal. nationalists know where they stand and do what they say they will. that's what i like in a government.

I am conservative on some ideals:
 
 I want a smaller government
 I want no abortion
 I think that we need to keep up a decent military
 I think that gun control is a stupid waste of money
 
 Of course, the government has actually expanded unde the last 4 republican presidents we have had, and shrunk under the democrats. I think that most of the republicans that have been elected to office hgave done quite a bit to strip us of our second amendment rights.
 
 I am also anti-death penalty. It costs a fortune to put somebody to death and serves no purpose. It is cheaper to put them in jail for life. I don't think the death penalty has anything to do with punisment. It is simply a remider to us all that if the government or society finds us objectionable enought, they can kill us. Either killing people is wrong or it isn't. If it is wrong, we shouldn't do it. If it isn't, then what are we making the big deal about when people are murdered?
 
 I think our foreign policy sucks
 
 I think minimum wage should be increased, illegal alienes should be deported, and farm subsidies should be ended. Farm subsidies are NOT designed to help farmers make more money. They are designed as a price control. 
 
 I also think that freedom means freedom from laws that are unneccessary. Laws about driving while talking on your cell phone, wearing helmets when you ride motorcycles, reporting students to the SRS who fail two hearing tests, and wearing seatbelts are WRONG. 
 
 Freedom sometimes means being able to raise your chiuldren as you see fit, say what you want, read what you want, and just generally make decisions based on what you feel is best for you. Unfortunatly, freedom also sometimes means being free to do things that are stupid. 
 
 I do not want or need a government to hold my hand and tell me how to live my life. I do not think we need so much governement that we all need to pay over half of our wages in some form of tax. I do not want a d#$n village to raise my children, I can do that just fine by myself, thank you.
 
 I am "other" I like some of the ideas of both parties, but am severely opposed to others.

It costs a fortune to put somebody to death and serves no purpose. It is cheaper to put them in jail for life.
 
 
 Don't you mean it the other way round? Death is cheaper than life imprisonment because all it costs is money to buy the bullets, and pay the firing squad, or buy the lethal injection. Anyway, it's cheaper than keeping them in prison for life because you have to feed them, clothe them etc, until they die! Way more expensive than the death penalty.

Don't you mean it the other way round? Death is cheaper than life imprisonment because all it costs is money to buy the bullets, and pay the firing squad, or buy the lethal injection. Anyway, it's cheaper than keeping them in prison for life because you have to feed them, clothe them etc, until they die! Way more expensive than the death penalty.

 
 That's incorrect, and anyone who believes that capital punishment is the most expedient form of viable punitive actions as far as costs go is ill informed and delusioned. Here, check this out:
 
 http://www.fguide.org/Bulletin/cappun.htm

I also agree with some that have said liberal and conservative is not so easy to define. On specifics issues, I don't think that it is unusual to break with the party that they are supposed to be in agreement with. Also, I think that there is some overlap in extremists. For example libertarians (a very conservative party) often believe marijuana should be legal, something I suspect George Bush would not agree with, but many left wingers do.
 
 So anyway, after my brief rant, I guess that I would say that I am liberal, at least to the extenct that everyone in American gets a fair shot.
 
 I grew up in a small midwestern town, believing that in America everyone had a fair shot, it was really about how hard you worked. I, however, went to a college in which a good number of people grew up much more privilged than I did, and much more than anyone I knew growing up. I have no problem with people being wealthy, but I never realized the kind of opportunities that often go along with growing up with privilege..education, social, etc. The fact is, if you are born wealthy, you are much more likely to succeed than if you grow up poor. In fact, people are not given anywhere close to equal oppurtunity. To me, this is not what I believe this country is supposed to be. Of course there are no rules saying that a poor person has to stay poor, but in a system that doesn't try to offer some kind of equal opportunity for everyone the poor stay poor, and the rich get richer, and you have a country where the most important factor in a person's success in who there parents are. I guess there are some who would call me a socialist for this, I think it is being an American.
 
 I could rant much more about this, but this has already gotten to be too long.

Don't you mean it the other way round? Death is cheaper than life imprisonment because all it costs is money to buy the bullets, and pay the firing squad, or buy the lethal injection. Anyway, it's cheaper than keeping them in prison for life because you have to feed them, clothe them etc, until they die! Way more expensive than the death penalty.

 
 
 NO. Look into this, we spend MILLIONS of dollars for each execution. In theory, you should be right. You can get a whole box of bullets, 50 rounds, for about $18. That is the good, high end bullets, too. This is not what we do, though. We have turned something so simple (like killing somebody) into a multi-million dollar fiasco. It is WAY cheaper to keep them in jai forever.
 
 Of course, the multi million dollar fiasco is needed in order to ensure that you aren't executing innocent people. Every time I hear that somebody has been found not-guilty and released from death row (which has happened several times, especially since the advent of DNA evidence), I have this flickering doubt about whether we should execute anybody, ever.

That is the good, high end bullets, too. This is not what we do, though. We have turned something so simple (like killing somebody) into a multi-million dollar fiasco.  I agree with all of this, and I would also like to mention that I have never seen a study that indicates that having the death penalty results in a decrease in violant crime. So, to me, at least, all that the death penalty does is to appease our sense of vengence. I am not sure that I am comfortable with such a government.

I think it does far more than appease our sense of vengance. One of the city marshals of Abilene, Ks (and I can't rememebr for sure which one it was) said "We like to hang somebody about once a month if we can. It reminds people who's in charge". This is what the death penalty does, it reminds us who is in charge.

I think it does far more than appease our sense of vengance. One of the city marshals of Abilene, Ks (and I can't rememebr for sure which one it was) said "We like to hang somebody about once a month if we can. It reminds people who's in charge". This is what the death penalty does, it reminds us who is in charge.

 
 
 I am not sure exactly what that means. But if it says that it does something to discourage violant crime, like I said, I have never seen a study that seems to support that. Like I said perhaps I don't understand what it meant by 'remind everyone who is in charge.'

I am not sure exactly what that means. But if it says that it does something to discourage violant crime, like I said, I have never seen a study that seems to support that. Like I said perhaps I don't understand what it meant by 'remind everyone who is in charge.'

 
 I have heard it said that the death penalty has less to do with crime than it does with reminding you that the government reservs the power to execute you if you are found to be objectionable enough. I think it is a power thing. I think what that marshal was saying is that he like to hang at least one person a month to remind the folks that HE was in charge.

I have heard it said that the death penalty has less to do with crime than it does with reminding you that the government reservs the power to execute you if you are found to be objectionable enough. I think it is a power thing. I think what that marshal was saying is that he like to hang at least one person a month to remind the folks that HE was in charge.

 
 
 To what purpose is this, though?

 I'm not endorsing the death penalty cost-wise, and I wouldn't endorse it otherwise. But I stand corrected. thanks for the article.
